headline.main: That's News to Him: Aaron Sorkin on 'The Newsroom' and His Steve Jobs Screenplay

docs.abstract: Aaron Sorkin, the creator of "The Newsroom," talks about balancing the writing of his new HBO series with film projects like "The Social Network" as well as upcoming assignments like a screenplay adapted from a best-selling biography of Steve Jobs.
docs.snippet: Aaron Sorkin, the creator of "The Newsroom," talks about balancing the writing of his new HBO series with film projects like "The Social Network" as well as upcoming assignments like a screenplay adapted from a best-selling biography of Steve Jobs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.

headline.seo: Tests of Parents Are Used to Map Genes of a Fetus
headline.main: DNA Blueprint for Fetus Built Using Tests of Parents
headline.print_headline: Tests Of Parents Are Used To Map Genes Of A Fetus

docs.abstract: Science Translational Medicine paper reports that researchers have been able to determine most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know the complete DNA blueprint of a child months before it is born; such mapping, which would allow thousands of genetic diseases to be detected prenatally, would raise serious ethical considerations.
docs.snippet: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: Misconceptions about how a drug works to prevent pregnancies may begin with what it’s called.

headline.main: Drug’s Nickname May Have Aided Politicization
headline.print_headline: Drug’s Nickname May Have Aided Politicization

docs.snippet: Misconceptions about how a drug works to prevent pregnancies may begin with what it’s called.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some abortion opponents say emergency contraception pills may block fertilized eggs from implanting, but scientists say there is no evidence the pills work that way.

headline.seo: Science at Issue in Debate on Morning-After Pill
headline.main: Abortion Qualms on Morning-After Pill May Be Unfounded
headline.print_headline: No Abortion Role Seen for Morning-After Pill

docs.abstract: Political debate over morning-after pills and abortion, a divisive election-year issue, is probably rooted in outdated or incorrect scientific guesses about how the pills work; studies, which support fact that pills delay ovulation, have not established that emergency contraceptive pills prevent fertilized eggs from implanting in the womb, an outcome that many abortion opponents consider the same as abortion (Series: Political Science).
docs.snippet: Some abortion opponents say emergency contraception pills may block fertilized eggs from implanting, but scientists say there is no evidence the pills work that way.

docs.lead_paragraph: Running a fever during pregnancy is associated with a risk of autism spectrum disorders and developmental delays in the offspring, a new study reports. Previous research has suggested a connection between autism and various infections during pregnancy, including measles, mumps, rubella and influenza.

headline.main: Vital Signs | Patterns: Fever in Pregnancy and Childhood Autism

docs.abstract: Dr Irva Hertz-Picciotto study in The Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders finds that running a fever during pregnancy is associated with a risk of autism spectrum disorders and developmental delays in the offspring. (M)/
